pervolitantia: <entryFree id="n35745" type="main" key="pervo^li^tanti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pervŏlĭtantĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>pervolito</etym>, <sense id="n35745.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a flying around</hi>, <hi rend="ital">circumvolation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mundi circa terram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:9:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 9, 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pervolito: <entryFree id="n35746" type="main" key="pervo^li^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pervŏlĭto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n35746.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. freq. n.</hi> [pervolo], <hi rend="ital">to fly through</hi> or <hi rend="ital">around</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to flit about</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">per dissepta domorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:952" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 952</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:346" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 346</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia loca,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tecta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:505" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 4, 505</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Transf.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">iter,</quote> <trans><tr>to traverse repeatedly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:9:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 9, 1, 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pervolo: <entryFree id="n35747" type="main" key="pervo^lo1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">per-vŏlo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <sense id="n35747.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n35747.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To fly through</hi> or <hi rend="ital">about</hi> a place: <cit><quote lang="la">aedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:473" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 473</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aërium iter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:252" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 252</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rumor agitatis pervolat alis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:6:527" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 527</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Flaminiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:61" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 61</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35747.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To fly</hi> to a place: Pegasus in nitentem pervolaturus aetheram, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Music. 3:3" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Music. 3, 3</bibl>: animus<cb n="PES" />  velocius in hanc sedem pervolabit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:26:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 26, 29</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n35747.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of swift motion in gen., <hi rend="ital">to fly</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dart through</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to pass quickly over</hi> or <hi rend="ital">through</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">perque volare mare ac terras (of the sun's beams),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 203</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sex et quinquaginta milia passuum cisiis pervolavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:7:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 7, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">totam urbem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:398" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 398</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">axe citato Flaminiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:60" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 60</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n35748" type="main" key="pervo^lo2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">per-vŏlo</orth>, <itype>vŏlui, velle</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n35748.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to wish greatly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be very desirous</hi> (rare but class.): <cit><quote lang="la">obtunso ore nunc pervelim progredire Senem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:5:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 5, 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scire ex te pervelim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:7:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sull. 7, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem videre pervellem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:11:14:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 11, 14, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi ignosci pervelim,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1, 3</bibl></cit>.—In tmesi: <cit><quote lang="la">ibi te quam primum per videre velim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 15, 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pervelle aliquid videre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud pervelim, proditum falso esse, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:18:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 18, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pervoluto: <entryFree id="n35749" type="main" key="pervo^lu_to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pervŏlūto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. freq. a.</pos> <etym>pervolvo</etym>, <sense id="n35749.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to roll over and over;</hi> hence, in partic., <hi rend="ital">to turn over</hi> books, <hi rend="ital">to look through</hi>, <hi rend="ital">read</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">libros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 12, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scriptores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:34:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 34, 158</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pervolutus: <entryFree id="n35750" type="main" key="pervolu_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pervolūtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from pervolvo.</entryFree>
pervolvo: <entryFree id="n35751" type="main" key="pervolvo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">per-volvo</orth>, <itype>volvi, vŏlūtum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n35751.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to roll</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tumble about</hi> (syn. voluto). </sense><sense id="n35751.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem in luto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:4:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 4, 38</bibl></cit>.—Mid., <hi rend="ital">to roll one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to roll</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in suo pervoluta sanguine,</quote> <trans><tr>weltering</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 8, p. 207, 22</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n35751.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to turn over</hi> a book, <hi rend="ital">to read</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Smyrnam incana diu saecula pervoluent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:95:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 95, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35751.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to be very busy</hi> or <hi rend="ital">much engaged</hi> in any thing: <cit><quote lang="la">ut in iis locis pervolvatur animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:35:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 35, 149</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pervorse: <entryFree id="n35752" type="main" key="pervorse_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pervorsē, pervorsus</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">pervorto</orth>, v. perverto.</entryFree>
pervulgate: <entryFree id="n35753" type="main" key="pervulga_te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pervulgātē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. pervulgo, <sense id="n35753.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
pervulgatus: <entryFree id="n35754" type="main" key="pervulga_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pervulgātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> and <pos>P. a.</pos>, from pervulgo.</entryFree>
pervulgo: <entryFree id="n35755" type="main" key="pervulgo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pervulgo</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-volgo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n35755.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to communicate to the people</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to make publicly known</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to publish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spread abroad</hi> (class.; cf. publico). </sense><sense id="n35755.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n35755.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1162</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">de re illustri et facile etiam in vulgus pervulgatā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:5:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 5, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in re tam clarā, tam testatā, tam abs te ipso pervulgatā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:42:section=104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 42, § 104</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illas tabulas pervulgari atque edi populo Romano imperavi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:15:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 15, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praemia virtutis in mediocribus hominibus pervulgari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:39:114" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 39, 114</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0478,001:Pet. Cons. 11:44" default="NO"><author>Q. Cic.</author> Pet. Cons. 11, 44</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n35755.3" n="B" level="2"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">to make one's self common</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to prostitute one's self</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulier, quae se omnibus pervulgaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:16:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 16, 38</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n35755.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to visit often</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to frequent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">haunt</hi> a place (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): litus pervolgans feror, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=88" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 88</bibl> Müll. (Trag. Rel. p. 108 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">solis pervolgant fulgura caelum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:164" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 164</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae pervolgant nemora avia pervolitantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:346" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 346</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:208" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 208</bibl>. —Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">pervulgātus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">pervolg-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n35755.5" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Very usual</hi>, <hi rend="ital">very common</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:9:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 9, 149</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">at hoc pervolgatum est nimis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 121</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consolatio pervulgata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:16:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 16, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">notius pervulgatiusque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:17:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 17, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pervulgatissima verborum dignitas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 8, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35755.6" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Well known</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">maledicta pervulgata in omnes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">humanitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:14:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 14, 9</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pervulgātē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">after the manner of the people</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as the vulgar do</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pervulgate magis quam inscite locutus es,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:10:6" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 10, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:7:12" default="NO">16, 7, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pes: <entryFree id="n35756" type="main" key="pe_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pēs</orth>, <itype>pĕdis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>kindr. with Sanscr. pād, foot, from root pad, ire; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">pod-, pou=s</foreign>; Goth. fōt; old Germ. vuoz; Engl. foot</etym>, <sense id="n35756.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a foot</hi> of man or beast. </sense><sense id="n35756.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">si pes condoluit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:22:52" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 22, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">calcei apti ad pedem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:54:231" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 54, 231</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec manus, nec pedes, nec alia membra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Univ. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pede tellurem pulsare,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to dance</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:37:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 37, 1</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">alterno pede terram quatere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 4, 7</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">4, 1, 27: pedis aptissima forma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aves omnes in pedes nascuntur,</quote> <trans><tr>are born feet first</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 53, 74, § 149</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cycnum pedibus Jovis armiger uncis Sustulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:564" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 564</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 723</bibl>: pedem ferre, <hi rend="ital">to go</hi> or <hi rend="ital">come</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si in fundo pedem posuisses,</quote> <trans><tr>set foot</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:11:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 11, 31</bibl></cit>: pedem efferre, <hi rend="ital">to step</hi> or <hi rend="ital">go out</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui pedem portā non extulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 2, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 8, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedem portā non plus extulit quam domo suā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: pedem limine efferre, <cb n="PES" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:14:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 14, 34</bibl>: pedem referre, revocare, retrahere, <hi rend="ital">to go</hi> or <hi rend="ital">come back</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to return</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">profugum referre pedem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 15, 186</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:439" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 2, 439</bibl>.—Said even of streams: <cit><quote lang="la">revocatque pedem Tiberinus ab alto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 125</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">retrahitque pedes simul unda relabens,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 307</bibl></cit>; cf. infra, II. H.: pedibus, <hi rend="ital">on foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">afoot</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ingressus iter pedibus sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:10:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 10, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:53" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 53</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Esp. in phrase: pedibus ire, venire, etc.: pedibus proficisci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedibus iter conficere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 44, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod flumen uno omnino loco pedibus transire potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Caesar) pedibus Narbonem pervenit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut neque pedibus aditum haberent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 3, 12 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>—Rarely pede ire (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">quo bene coepisti, sic pede semper eas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:9:66" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 1, 9, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Jordanem transmiserunt pede,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> in Psa. 118, 165</bibl></cit>, n. 16.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Bacchus flueret pede suo,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>wine unmixed with water</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Aetn.</author> 13</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">musta sub adducto si pede nulla fluant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:9:32" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 9, 32</bibl></cit>, and II. H. infra.—Pregn., <hi rend="ital">by land</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum illud iter Hispaniense pedibus fere confici soleat: aut si quis navigare velit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Vatin. 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">seu pedibus Parthos sequimur, seu classe Britannos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:20:63" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 20, 63</bibl></cit> (3, 23, 5): <cit><quote lang="la">ego me in pedes (conicio),</quote> <trans><tr>take to my heels</tr>, <tr>make off</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 2, 5</bibl></cit>.— Esp.: ad pedes alicui or alicujus, accidere, procidere, jacere, se abicere, se proicere, procumbere, etc., <hi rend="ital">to approach as a suppliant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to fall at one's feet</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad pedes omnium singillatim accidente Clodio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:14:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 14, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abjectā togā se ad generi pedes abiecit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rex procidit ad pedes Achillei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:17:14" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 17, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vos ad pedes lenonis proiecistis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:11:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 11, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">filius se ad pedes meos prosternens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:18:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 18, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tibi sum supplex, Nec moror ante tuos procubuisse pedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:12:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 12, 186</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui cum se moesta turba ad pedes provolvisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad pedes Caesaris provoluta regina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:11:9" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 11, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(mater una) mihi ad pedes misera jacuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:49:section=129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 49, § 129</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">amplecti pedes potui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:605" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 605</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">complector, regina, pedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:10:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 10, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">servus a pedibus,</quote> <trans><tr>a footman</tr>, <tr>lackey</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 5, 1</bibl></cit>: sub pedibus, <hi rend="ital">under one's feet</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">in one's power</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 100</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 32</bibl>: sub pedibus esse or jacere, <hi rend="ital">to be</hi> or <hi rend="ital">lie under one's feet</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to be disregarded</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">sors ubi pessima rerum, Sub pedibus timor est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:490" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 490</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amicitiae nomen Re tibi pro vili sub pedibusque jacet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:8:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 1, 8, 16</bibl></cit>: pedem opponere, <hi rend="ital">to put one's foot against</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to withstand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">resist</hi>, <hi rend="ital">oppose</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:6:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> P. 4, 6, 8</bibl>: pedem trahere, <hi rend="ital">to drag one's foot</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to halt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">limp;</hi> said of scazontic verse, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> R. Am. 378</bibl>: trahantur haec pedibus, <hi rend="ital">may be dragged by the heels</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">may go to the dogs</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">fratrem mecum et te si habebo, per me ista pedibus trahantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:16:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 16, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:32:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 32, 2</bibl>: ante pedes esse or ante pedes posita esse, <hi rend="ital">to lie before one's feet</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">before one's eyes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be evident</hi>, <hi rend="ital">palpable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">glaring</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">istuc est sapere, non quod ante pedes modo est, Videre, sed etiam illa, quae futura sunt, Prospicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">transilire ante pedes posita, et alia longe repetita sumere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:40:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 40, 160</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omni pede stare,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to use every effort</tr>, <tr>make every exertion</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:9:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 9, 18</bibl></cit>: nec caput nec pes, <hi rend="ital">neither head nor foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">beginning nor end</hi>, <hi rend="ital">no part</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec caput nec pes sermonum apparet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 3, 139</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">garriet quoi neque pes neque caput conpareat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 81</bibl></cit>: tuas res ita contractas, ut, quemadmodum scribis, nec caput nec pedes, Curio ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:31:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 31, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut nec pes nec caput uni Reddatur formae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dixit Cato, eam legationem nec caput, nec pedes, nec cor habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Epit. 50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> Epit. 50</bibl></cit>: pes felix, secundus, i. e. <hi rend="ital">a happy</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fortunate arrival</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adi pede secundo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:302" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 302</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">felix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:514" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 514</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">boni pedis homo, id est cujus adventus afferat aliquid felicitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. ad Max. Gram. 44" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. ad Max. Gram. 44</bibl></cit>.—So esp. pes dexter, because it was of good omen to move the right foot first; <cit><quote lang="la">temples had an uneven number of steps, that the same foot might touch the first step and first enter the temple,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3, 3</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quove pede ingressi?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3</bibl></cit> (4), 1, 6.—So the left foot was associated with bad omens; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:92" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 92 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pessimo pede domum nostram accessit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 6, 26, p. 184, 1</bibl></cit>; hence, dextro pede, <hi rend="ital">auspiciously</hi>: quid tam dextro <pb n="1363" /> <cb n="PESC" /> pede concipis, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:5" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 5</bibl>: pedibus pecunia compensatur, said proverbially of distant lands purchased at a cheap rate, but which it costs a great deal to reach, Cato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 29, 72</bibl>: a pedibus usque ad caput, <hi rend="ital">from head to foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">all over</hi> (late Lat.; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ab imis unguibus usque ad verticem summum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:7:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Com. 7, 20</bibl></cit>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:in Psa. 55:20" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> in Psa. 55, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:90:1:2" default="NO">90, 1, 2</bibl> et saep.; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">a vestigio pedis usque ad verticem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> Offic. Min. 2, 22, 114</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.2" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n35756.3" n="1" level="3"> <usg type="dom">Milit. t. t.</usg>: descendere ad pedes, <hi rend="ital">to alight</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dismount</hi>, of cavalry, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedibus merere,</quote> <trans><tr>to serve on foot</tr>, <tr>as a foot-soldier</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad pedes pugna ierat,</quote> <trans><tr>they fought on foot</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 46</bibl></cit>: pedem conferre, <hi rend="ital">to come to close quarters</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">collato pede rem gerere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 26, 39</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:19:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 19, 48</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.4" n="2" level="3"> Publicist's t. t.: pedibus ire in sententiam alicujus, <hi rend="ital">to adopt one's opinion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">take sides with one</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum omnes in sententiam ejus pedibus irent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:8:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 8, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 9, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.5" n="3" level="3"> In mal. part.: <cit><quote lang="la">pedem or pedes tollere, extollere (ad concubitum),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:81:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 81, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:11:71:8" default="NO">11, 71, 8</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence the lusus verbb. with pedem dare and tollere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 1, 5</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n35756.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n35756.7" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A foot</hi> of a table, stool, bench, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:2:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 2, 46</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mensae sed erat pes tertius impar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:661" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 661</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">pedem et nostrum dicimus, et lecti, et veli, ut carminis (v. in the foll.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 2:34:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 2, 34, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tricliniorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 2, 4, § 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">subsellii,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 55, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pes argenteus (mensae),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:11:128" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 11, 128</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.8" n="B" level="2"> Pes veli, <hi rend="ital">a rope attached to a sail</hi> for the purpose of setting it to the wind, <hi rend="ital">a sheet</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sive utrumque Juppiter Simul secundus incidisset in pedem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:4:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 4, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pede labitur aequo,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>before the wind</tr>, <tr>with the wind right aft</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:565" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 565</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedibus aequis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 6 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>; cf. also the passage quoted above from <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 2:34:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 2, 34, 2</bibl>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">prolato pede, transversos captare Notos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Med. 322" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Med. 322</bibl></cit>.— Hence, facere pedem, <hi rend="ital">to veer out one sheet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to take advantage of a side wind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to haul the wind</hi>: una omnes fecere pedem; <cit><quote lang="la">pariterque sinistros, Nunc dextros solvere sinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:830" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 830</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prolatis pedibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 47, 48, § 128</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.9" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The foot</hi> of a mountain (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">Orontes imos pedes Casii montis praetermeans,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 8, 10 al.</bibl></cit>— </sense><sense id="n35756.10" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Ground</hi>, <hi rend="ital">soil</hi>, <hi rend="ital">territory</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">in Caesariensis pede,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnis Africa Zeugitano pede incipit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 27, 1</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quamvis angustum pedem dispositio fecit habitabilem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Tranq. An. 10:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Tranq. An. 10, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.11" n="E" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The stalk</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pedicle</hi> of a fruit, esp. of the grape, together with the husk: <cit><quote lang="la">vinaceorum pes proruitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:43" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 43</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 36</bibl>.—Of the olive, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 1, 2, § 5</bibl>: pes milvinus or milvi, <hi rend="ital">the stalk</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stem of the plant</hi> batis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:7" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 7</bibl>.—Hence, as a name for several plants: pedes gallinacei, <hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Capnos trunca, quam pedes gallinaceos vocant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:155" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 13, 98, § 155</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedes betacei,</quote> <trans><tr>beetroots</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:27" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.12" n="F" level="1"> Pedes navales, <hi rend="ital">rowers</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sailors</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:2:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 2, 2, 75</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.13" n="G" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The barrow</hi> of a litter, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:10:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 10, 22</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.14" n="H" level="1"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, of fountains and rivers: inde super terras fluit agmine dulci, Quā via secta semel liquido pede detulit undas, Lucr, 5, 272; <cit><quote lang="la">6, 638: crepante lympha desilit pede,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:16:47" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 16, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">liquido pede labitur unda,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> Cul. 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lento pede sulcat harenas Bagrada,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:140" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 6, 140</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.15" n="K" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A metrical foot</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad heroum nos dactyli et anapaesti et spondei pedem invitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:47:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 47, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedibus claudere verba,</quote> <trans><tr>to make verses</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:1:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 1, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">musa per undenos emodulanda pedes,</quote> <trans><tr>in hexameters and pentameters</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:1:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 1, 1, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inque suos volui cogere verba pedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:12:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 5, 12, 34</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.16" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A kind of verse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">measure</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">et pede, quo debent fortia bella geri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:646" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 646</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Lesbius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:6:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 6, 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.17" n="L" level="1"> In music, <hi rend="ital">time</hi> (postAug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 29, 1, 5, § 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.18" n="M" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A foot</hi>, as a measure of length (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">ne iste hercle ab istā non pedem discedat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 3, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab aliquo pedem discessisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:15:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 15, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedem e villā adhuc egressi non sumus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:16:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 16, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pes justus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:317" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 31, 74, § 317</bibl></cit>.—Hence, transf.: pede suo se metiri, <hi rend="ital">to measure one's self by one's own foot-rule</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">by one's own powers</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abilities</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 7, 98</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n35756.19" n="N" level="1"> Pedes, <hi rend="ital">lice;</hi> v. pedis.—</sense><sense id="n35756.20" n="O" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The leg</hi> (late Lat.), in phrase: pedem frangere, Aug. Civ. Dei, 22, 22, 3; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Serm. 273, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pescennius: <entryFree id="n35757" type="main" key="Pescenni^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Pescennĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n35757.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens. </sense><sense id="n35757.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A friend of Cicero</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:14:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 14, 4, 6</bibl>.—Esp., </sense><sense id="n35757.2" n="II" level="1"> Pescennius Niger, <hi rend="ital">a Roman<cb n="PESS" />  emperor;</hi> hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Pescenniānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the emperor Pescennius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">reliquiae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Sev. 15, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Pesc. Nig. 12, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pescia: <entryFree id="n35758" type="gloss" key="pescia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pescia</orth> <itype>in Saliari carmine Aelius Stilo dici ait capitia ex pellibus agninis facta, quod Graeci pelles vocent pesce neutro genere pluraliter</itype>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=210" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 210</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
pesestas: <entryFree id="n35759" type="gloss" key="pesestas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pesestas</orth> <itype>significare videtur pestilentiam</itype>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=210" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 210</bibl> Müll.; cf.: pesestas dicebatur pestilentia, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=211" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 211</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
pesnis: <entryFree id="n35760" type="gloss" key="pesnis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pesnis</orth>, <itype>for pennis</itype>, acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=205" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 205</bibl> Müll.; v. penna.</entryFree>
pesoluta: <entryFree id="n35761" type="main" key="pesoluta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pesoluta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n35761.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an Egyptian plant used for making garlands</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:184" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 33, 108, § 184</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pessarium: <entryFree id="n35762" type="main" key="pessa_ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessārĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>2. pessum</etym>, <sense id="n35762.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a pessary</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 3:18:185" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 3, 18, 185</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 3, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pessime: <entryFree id="n35763" type="main" key="pessi^me_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessĭmē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. 1. <itype>malus</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos></entryFree>
pessimo: <entryFree id="n35764" type="main" key="pessi^mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessĭmo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>pessimus</etym>, <sense id="n35764.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make utterly bad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to spoil completely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to ruin</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">plebem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Ecclus. 36, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">te ipsum pessimabis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 38, 22</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pessimabor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Ecclus. 11, 26</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pessimus: <entryFree id="n35765" type="main" key="pessi^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessĭmus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. 1. malus.</entryFree>
pessinus: <entryFree id="n35766" type="main" key="Pessi^nu_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Pessĭnūs</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Pesĭnūs</orth>, <itype>untis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (<sense id="n35766.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">acc. masc.</hi> Pessinuntem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:13:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Har. Resp. 13, 28</bibl>), = <foreign lang="greek">*pessinou=s</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">*pesinou=s</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a very ancient town in Galatia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the borders of Phrygia Major</hi>, <hi rend="ital">celebrated for its worship of Cybele;</hi> the modern <hi rend="ital">Bala Hissar</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 12, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si mater Idaea a Pessinunte Romam advecta foret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 10</bibl></cit> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 32, 42, § 146</bibl>, the true read. is Pisinuus). —Hence, </sense><sense id="n35766.1" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Pessĭnuntĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Pessinuntic; as subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Pessĭnun-tĭca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">Cybele</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11, p. 259, 7</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n35766.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Pessĭnuntĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Pessinuntian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sacerdos magnae Matris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:26:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 26, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aselli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:16:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 16, 5</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pessulum: <entryFree id="n35767" type="main" key="pessu^lum1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessŭlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>pessum</etym>, <sense id="n35767.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a pessary</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 3:18:184" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 3, 18, 184</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n35768" type="main" key="pessu^lum2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessŭlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. pessulus <sense id="n35768.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
pessulus: <entryFree id="n35769" type="main" key="pessu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<sense id="n35769.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">neutr.</hi> collat. form in <number>plur.</number> pessula, <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Carm. 18, 412</bibl>) [<foreign lang="greek">pa/ssalos</foreign>], <hi rend="ital">a bolt</hi> (ante- and post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">occlude sis fores ambobus pessulis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:1:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 1, 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pessuli, heus pessuli, vos saluto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:2:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 1, 2, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pessulum ostio obdo,</quote> <trans><tr>shoot the bolt</tr>, <tr>lock the door</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:5:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 5, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">foribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pessulos inicere,</quote> <trans><tr>to shoot the bolts</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 3, p. 135, 39</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1</bibl>, p. 107, 12; <cit><quote lang="la">p. 108, 24: aperire: pessulum ostii mei aperui dilecto meo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,031:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Cant. 5, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pessum: <entryFree id="n35770" type="main" key="pessum1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessum</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>prob. contr. from pedis-versum, <foreign lang="greek">pe/ca, pe/don</foreign>, towards the feet; like susum, sursum, from sub-versum; hence, in gen.</etym>, <sense id="n35770.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to the ground</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to the bottom</hi>, <hi rend="ital">down</hi> (mostly ante-class. and postAug.; esp. freq. in the connection pessum ire and pessum dare). </sense><sense id="n35770.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc eam (cistellulam) cum navi scilicet abisse pessum in altum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:3:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 3, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quando abiit rete pessum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 1, 1, 15</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">ne pessum abeat (ratis),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:4:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 4, 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multae per mare pessum Subsedere urbes,</quote> <trans><tr>have gone to the bottom</tr>, <tr>been swallowed up</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:589" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 589</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi dulcem caseum demiseris in eam (muriam), si pessum ibit, etc. (opp. si innatabit),</quote> <trans><tr>goes to the bottom</tr>, <tr>sinks</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:6:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 6, 2</bibl></cit> (cf. also the fig. taken from a ship, in II.): <cit><quote lang="la">ut (lacus) folia non innatantia ferat, sed pessum et penitus accipiat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:9:2" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 9, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sidentia pessum Corpora caesa tenent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:674" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 674</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam celsa cacumina pessum Tellus victa dedit,</quote> <trans><tr>sent to the bottom</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:616" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 616</bibl></cit>: pessum mergere pedes, Prud. praef. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:36" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> 2, 36</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n35770.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n35770.3" n="A" level="2"> Pessum ire, and rarely pessum sidere, <hi rend="ital">to fall to the ground</hi>, <hi rend="ital">go to ruin; to sink</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perish</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quia miser non eo pessum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:2:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 2, 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pessum ituros fecundissimos Italiae campos, si, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pessum iere vitae pretia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:H. N. 14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> H. N. 14</bibl></cit> prooem. § <cit><quote lang="la">5: vitia civitatis degenerantis et pessum suā mole sidentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Const. Sap. 2:3" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Const. Sap. 2, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35770.4" n="B" level="2"> Pessum dare (less correctly, in one word, pessumdare or pessundare), rarely pessum premere, agere, deicere, <hi rend="ital">to send to the bottom</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to sink</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ruin</hi>, <hi rend="ital">destroy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">undo; to put out of the world</hi>, <hi rend="ital">put an end to</hi>: pessum dare aliquem verbis, Cic. Fragm. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:47" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 6, 47</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pessum dedisti me blandimentis tuis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:6:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 6, 23</bibl></cit>; id. Merc. <cb n="PEST" /> 5, 2, 6: <cit><quote lang="la">exemplum pessumum pessum date,</quote> <trans><tr>do away with</tr>, <tr>remove</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae res plerumque magnas civitates pessum dedit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 42:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 42, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae, si non astu providentur, me aut erum pessum dabunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 3, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multos etiam bonos pessum dedit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 66 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingentes hostium copias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:4:4:5" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 4, 4, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sin (animus) ad inertiam et voluptates corporis pessumdatus est,</quote> <trans><tr>has sunk into indolence</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem pro suis factis pessumis pessum premere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:2:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 5, 2, 49</bibl></cit>: aetate pessum actā, i. e. <hi rend="ital">brought to an end</hi>, Auct. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 1, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec sum mulier, nisi eam pessum de tantis opibus dejecero,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 5, p. 161, 22</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5</bibl>, p. 163, 22.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n35771" type="greek" key="pessum2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (collat. form <orth extent="full" lang="la">pes-sus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Plin. Val.</author> 1, 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 2, 5</bibl>), = <foreign lang="greek">pesso/n, pesso/s</foreign>, in medic. lang., <sense id="n35771.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a pessary</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 121</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 3, 5</bibl> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 21</bibl>, written as Greek).</sense></entryFree>
pessumdo: <entryFree id="n35772" type="main" key="pessumdo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessumdo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">pessun-</orth>), <itype>dăre</itype>, v. 1. pessum, II. B.</entryFree>
pessus: <entryFree id="n35773" type="main" key="pessus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pessus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, v. 2. pessum <sense id="n35773.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
pestibilis: <entryFree id="n35774" type="main" key="pesti^bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭbĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pestis</etym>, <sense id="n35774.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pestilential</hi>, <hi rend="ital">destructive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">noxious</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">fundus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 4, 58, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pestifer: <entryFree id="n35775" type="main" key="pesti^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭfer</orth> <itype>and</itype> (rarely, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 6</bibl>) <orth extent="full" lang="la">pes-tĭfĕrus</orth>, <itype>ĕra, ĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pestis-fero</etym>. <sense id="n35775.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Bringing pestilence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pestilential</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">odor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:26:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 26, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35775.1" n="II" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">that brings destruction</hi>, <hi rend="ital">destructive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">baleful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">noxious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pernicious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pestiferous</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">res pestiferae et nocentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:47:120" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 47, 120</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accessus ad res salutares, a pestiferis recessus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 12, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acutus et pestifer morbus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:4:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 4, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sudor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:594" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 4, 594</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:477" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 477</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fames,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:8:784" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 784</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fauces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:570" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 570</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aër,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:10:331" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 10, 331</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bella civilia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:25:86" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 25, 86</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Antonii pestifer reditus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 3, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:24:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 24, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestiferum fulgur dicitur, quo mors exsiliumve significari solet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=210" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 210</bibl></cit> Müll.; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">pestifera quae mortem aut exsilium ostendunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=245" default="NO"><author>id.</author> p. 245</bibl></cit> ib.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭfer</orth>, <itype>ĕri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a mischievous person</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Ecclus. 11, 35</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭfĕrĕ</orth>, <hi rend="ital">balefully</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pestiferously</hi> (rare but class.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:5:13" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 5, 13</bibl>; Hilar. Trin. 7, 3.</sense></entryFree>
pestilens: <entryFree id="n35776" type="main" key="pesti^lens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭlens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pestis</etym>, <sense id="n35776.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pestilential</hi>, <hi rend="ital">infected</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unhealthy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unwholesome</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n35776.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">loci (opp. salubres),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:4:7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fat. 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestilens et gravis aspiratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:57:130" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 57, 130</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Africus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:23:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 23, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:13:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 13, 54</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">annus urbi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestas animalibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 16</bibl></cit>. —<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fundus pestilentior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">annus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 21</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gravissimus et pestilentissimus annus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:16:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 16, 4</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n35776.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">pestilent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">noxious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">destructive</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">homo pestilentior patriā suā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:24:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 24, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestilens collegae munus esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invidia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Hippol. 489" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Hippol. 489</bibl></cit>. —<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭlens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a pestilent fellow</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,023:15:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Macc. 15, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pestilentia: <entryFree id="n35777" type="main" key="pesti^lenti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭlentĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>pestilens</etym>, <sense id="n35777.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an infectious</hi> or <hi rend="ital">contagious disease</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a plague</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pestilence.</hi> </sense><sense id="n35777.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">Massilienses gravi pestilentiā conflictati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:5:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 5, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestilentia gravis incidit in urbem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestilentiae contagia prohibere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:157" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 8, 80, § 157</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 7</bibl> <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n35777.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">an unwholesome atmosphere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">weather</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">region</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">agrorum genus propter pestilentiam vastum atque desertum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:26:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 26, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestilentiae signa (opp. signa salubritatis),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:5:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 5, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestilentiae possessores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:1:5:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 1, 5, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35777.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a plague</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pestilence</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in postclass. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">oratio plena veneni et pestilentiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:44:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 44, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cathedra pestilentiae,</quote> <trans><tr>the seat of the scornful</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 1, 1</bibl></cit>.— In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">animorum labes et pestilentiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:2:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 2, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pestilentiarius: <entryFree id="n35778" type="main" key="pesti^lenti^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭlentĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pestilentia</etym>, <sense id="n35778.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pestilential</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">cathedra,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Spect. 27</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pestilentiosus: <entryFree id="n35779" type="main" key="pesti^lenti^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭlentĭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n35779.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pestilential</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unhealthy</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">locus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:43:8:2:section=29" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 43, 8, 2, § 29</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
pestilentus: <entryFree id="n35780" type="main" key="pesti^lentus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭlentus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pestis</etym>, <sense id="n35780.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pestilential</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unhealthy</hi> (ante-class. for pestilens): loca, Laevius ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:7:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 7, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
pestilis: <entryFree id="n35781" type="main" key="pesti^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n35781.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pestilential</hi>, <hi rend="ital">un wholesome</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">aurae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 1, 11</bibl></cit>. <pb n="1364" /> <cb n="PETA" /></sense></entryFree>
pestilitas: <entryFree id="n35782" type="main" key="pesti^li^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭlĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>pestilis</etym>, <sense id="n35782.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">plague</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pestilence</hi>, for pestilentia (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1098" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1098</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1125" default="NO" valid="yes">1125</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1132" default="NO" valid="yes">1132</bibl> (the first verse also quoted by <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 158, 2</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
pestimus: <entryFree id="n35783" type="gloss" key="pesti^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestĭmus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>pestis</etym>, <sense id="n35783.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">plaguebringing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pestilential</hi>: <foreign lang="greek">loimofo/ros</foreign>, pestimus, Gloss. Gr. Lat.</sense></entryFree>
pestis: <entryFree id="n35784" type="main" key="pestis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pestis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>perh. for perd-tis, from perdo</etym>, <sense id="n35784.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a deadly</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">an infectious</hi> or <hi rend="ital">contagious disease</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a plague</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pestilence;</hi> also, <hi rend="ital">a noxious atmosphere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unhealthy weather</hi> (class., but rare for pestilentia; cf. contagio, lues). </sense><sense id="n35784.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: hos pestis necuit, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 861</bibl> P. (Ann. v. 549 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">ibes avertunt pestem ab Aegypto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:36:101" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 36, 101</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">avertere a populo pestem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:25:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 25, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:14" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:26" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alii aliā peste absumpti sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 19</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">crudelem nasorum interfice pestem,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>stinking smell</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:69:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 69, 9</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">in omnibus morbis ac pestibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:5" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 7, 5</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin;</hi> 2, 9, 9 sq.—</sense><sense id="n35784.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">destruction</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ruin</hi>, <hi rend="ital">death</hi> (class.): qui alteri exitium parat, Eum scire oportet, sibi paratam pestem ut participet parem, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:17:39" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 17, 39</bibl> (Trag. v. 22 Vahl.); so with exitium, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:21:42" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 21, 42</bibl> (Trag. v. 68 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">quanta pernis pestis veniet!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 3, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:347" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 347</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">detestabilis pestis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:5:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 5, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestis ac pernicies civitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Perd. 1, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">9, 25</bibl>: priusquam oppeto malam pestem (= subeo mortem), Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:16:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 16, 38</bibl> (Trag. v. 15 Vahl.); so, <cit><quote lang="la">occidam oppetamque pestem,</quote> <trans><tr>will seek my death</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 3, 11</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 1, 1, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">servatae a peste carinae,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>from the fire</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:699" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 699</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestem miserrimam importare alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:15:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 15, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">machinari alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:26:67" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 26, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">minitari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 49</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n35784.3" n="B" level="2"> Concr., of a destructive thing or person, <hi rend="ital">a pest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">curse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bane</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin unā omnes peste hac populum liberant?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">peste interimor textili (of the poisoned and fatal garment of Nessus), Cic. poët. Tusc. 2, 8, 20: coluber, Pestis boum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:419" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 419</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illa furia ac pestis patriae (of Clodius),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sest. 14, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">post abitum hujus importunissimae pestis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 54, § 125</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec saevior ulla Pestis et ira deūm (of the Harpies),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:214" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 214</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestes frugum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 25, 77, § 160</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">of Nero: clade et peste sub illā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:4:84" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 4, 84</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaedam pestes hominum,</quote> <trans><tr>social pests</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:8:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 8, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">variae pestes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:181" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 181</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corporeae pestes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:737" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 6, 737</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
peta: <entryFree id="n35785" type="main" key="Pe^ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Pĕta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>peto</etym>, <sense id="n35785.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the goddess of praying</hi> or <hi rend="ital">entreaty</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 4, 131</bibl>.‡ † <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕtălum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">pe/talon</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a metal plate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">petalum, aurea lamina in fronte pontificis, quae nomen Dei tetragrammaton Hebraicis litteris habebat scriptum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 29, 21</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
petaminarius: <entryFree id="n35786" type="main" key="pe^ta^mi^na_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕtămĭnārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">peta/menos</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n35786.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tumbler</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rope-dancer</hi> (post-class.), Firm. Math. 8, 15; <bibl default="NO"><author>Salv.</author> Gub. D. 6, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
petasatus: <entryFree id="n35787" type="main" key="pe^ta^sa_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕtăsātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>petasus</etym>, <sense id="n35787.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">with a travelling-cap on</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">ready for a journey</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">petasati veniunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:17:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 15, 17, 1</bibl></cit>; Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 4, 319</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:82" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 82</bibl>; Hier. prooem. in Zachar. 1, 2.</sense></entryFree>
petasio: <entryFree id="n35788" type="greek" key="pe^ta^si^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕtăsĭo</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕtăso</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">petasw/n</foreign>, <sense id="n35788.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a leg</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pestle of pork</hi>, esp. the shoulder (opp. perna, the ham): <cit><quote lang="la">e Galliā apportantur Romam pernae tomacinae et taniacae, et petasiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:4:10" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pulpam dubio de petasone voras,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>that has already begun to turn</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:77:6" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 3, 77, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
petasunculus: <entryFree id="n35789" type="main" key="pe^ta^suncu^lus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕtăsuncŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>petaso</etym>, <sense id="n35789.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little leg</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pestle of pork</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">siccus petasunculus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:119" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 119</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n35790" type="main" key="pe^ta^suncu^lus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕtăsuncŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>petasus</etym>, <sense id="n35790.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small travelling-cap</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 6, 198</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
petasus: <entryFree id="n35791" type="greek" key="pe^ta^sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕtăsus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">pe/tasos</foreign>, <sense id="n35791.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a travelling hat</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cap</hi>, with a broad brim (cf.: pileus, cucullus). </sense><sense id="n35791.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:2:4:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 2, 4, 45</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 7, 90</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. prol. 143</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 6, 197</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n35791.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, something in the shape of a cap, placed on a building, <hi rend="ital">a cap</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cupola</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 13, 19, § 92</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
petaurista: <entryFree id="n35792" type="greek" key="pe^taurista"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕtaurista</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">-es</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">petauristh/s</foreign>, <sense id="n35792.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tumbler</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vaulter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rope-dancer.</hi> </sense><sense id="n35792.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: petauristae a veteribus dicebantur qui saltibus vel schemis levioribus moverentur, et haec proprietas a Graecā nominatione descendit, <foreign lang="greek">a)po\ tou= peta=sqai</foreign>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 56, 26</bibl>; Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 1</bibl>. 1.; cf.: petauristas Lucilius a petauro appellatos existimare videtur. At Aelius Stilo, quod in aëre volent,<cb n="PETI" />  <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=206" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 206</bibl> Müll.—</sense><sense id="n35792.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of animals that leap very high, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 33, 39, § 115</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
petauristarius: <entryFree id="n35793" type="greek" key="pe^taurista_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">pĕtauristārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>petaurista</etym>, <sense id="n35793.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tumbler</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rope-dancer</hi> (post-Aug.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 53</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">60</bibl>; Firm. Math. 8, 15.</sense></entryFree>
